title: 111_hr5113
content: The Child Nutrition Act of 1966 is amended to include a new section on Local Wellness Policy and Healthy Habits Challenge Program. Each local educational agency must establish a local school wellness policy by the first day of the school year after June 30, 2010, with goals for nutrition education, physical activity, and promoting student wellness through school-based activities. This policy must include nutrition guidelines for all available foods. The local educational agency must establish a wellness policy for all foods available on school campuses to promote student health and reduce childhood obesity. The policy should meet guidelines for school meals set by the Secretary and include a plan for measuring implementation. The implementation of the local wellness policy involves designating individuals responsible for ensuring policy compliance and engaging parents, students, and various stakeholders in policy development. Technical assistance and best practices are provided through coordination between the Secretary of Education and the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, through the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, offers information and technical assistance to promote healthy school nutrition environments, reduce childhood obesity, and prevent diet-related chronic diseases. The Secretary of Health and Human Services provides technical assistance to schools and local educational agencies to promote healthy food options and establish nutrition environments consistent with the goals of reducing childhood obesity and chronic diseases. This includes offering examples of model school wellness policies. The Secretary establishes the Healthy Habits School Challenge Program to reduce childhood obesity by promoting good nutrition and physical activity in schools. The Program is for guidance purposes only and not binding on educational agencies. The Healthy Habits School Challenge Program requires schools to demonstrate adoption of a wellness policy and provide nutrition education to students. The school must offer physical education classes to students in certain grade levels as part of required instruction. The school must offer structured physical education classes to students in at least 2 grade levels and provide opportunities for physical activity throughout the school year. Additionally, the school must adhere to the most recent nutrition rules set by the Secretary. The school must comply with the Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act by offering foods in school nutrition programs and maintaining records of student participation in physical activities. The school must comply with the Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act by offering foods in school nutrition programs, maintaining records of student participation in physical activities, and achieving specific benchmarks related to student consumption of fresh fruits and vegetables and the availability of healthy meal alternatives in the cafeteria. The Secretary will develop these benchmarks within 90 days of the enactment of this subsection. The Secretary and the Secretary of Education will determine benchmarks for receiving distinction under the Program, with levels of distinction available. Definitions for elementary, middle, and high schools are provided. The term 'high school' refers to a public school with grades 9 to 12 as determined by State law. Updating nutrition rules under the Richard B. Russell National School Lunch Act by entering into a contract with the Institute of Medicine for recommendations. A conforming amendment repeals Section 204 of the Child Nutrition and WIC Reauthorization Act of 2004.
